The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense debate. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum theory. The present paper provides a categorical characterization of Hilbert space, which is the mathematical substrate of quantum theory. The characterization is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The characterization is also complete in the sense that it is possible to prove that a category is equivalent to that of Hilbert spaces if and only if it satisfies the axioms. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in these reconstruction programs. The paper also provides a categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert spaces, which is a fundamental object in quantum theory. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are of great importance in aquaculture and human health. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unclear. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two myxozoans, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the genome and transcriptome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. (Show more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The virus responsible for this pandemic, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), is able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2. In this study, we show that the viral accessory protein ORF6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings provide a potential target for the development of antiviral drugs against COVID-19. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century. Meeting the food demand of this growing population will become increasingly challenging as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation (SD) of yields and a decrease in mean yields. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results have implications for understanding the role of large mammals in ecosystem functioning and biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses anticipate difficulties accessing the CARES Act, which is intended to provide grants to small businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most pervasive forms of pollution in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris, which involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Our results point at the need for a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the Solar System is one of the most important questions in science. The age of the Solar System is determined by the age of the oldest meteorites. The age of the oldest meteorites is determined by the age of the oldest presolar grains. The age of the oldest presolar grains is determined by the age of the oldest grains that produced them. We determined the age of the oldest presolar grains in a meteorite.

We provide a comprehensive picture of the evolution of the global fishing fleet, its fishing effort, and the effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) since the 1950s. We show that the global fleet has doubled in size, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since 1950, but this trend has been reversed in recent years. The global fleet is expected to continue to grow, but the rate of expansion is slowing.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of sociality. Here, we show that the evolution of domestication and the evolution of allonursing both increase the energy available to the mother and that this increase in energy is associated with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability. Rather, it is due to an increase in the metabolic power of the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotective effects in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. Our findings also provide a rationale for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in other synucleinopathies. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels. It is a single layer of cells that is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized in a network of cells that is highly efficient in the communication of information. The endothelium is able to rapidly and robustly communicate with each other, and the communication is organized in a way that is effective for both local and global communication. The endothelium is thus able to control the cardiovascular system in a highly efficient and effective way.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis. In the United States, the pandemic has been characterized by a rapid rise in cases and deaths, followed by a rapid decline. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to the data and information that have been critical to understanding and responding to the pandemic. The API provides data on cases, deaths, and hospitalizations, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The activation gate is the part of the channel that opens and closes the channel. In this work, we show that the activation gate can affect the structure of the selectivity filter, and vice versa.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health and disease is being investigated, and the development of new therapeutics is a major focus of research. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system, and the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the environment. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain structure that is critical for social behavior. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. These findings also suggest that the brain energy metabolism may be a target for the development of new treatments for social disorders. (Show more)

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses under large deformation is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a digital synthesis approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. It also provides a digital synthesis approach for the design of multifunctional materials and structures. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the life span of humans. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of aging. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is a key player in the regulation of fetal hemoglobin expression.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the survival rate of patients with advanced cancer remains low. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. We found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which is highly frequent in cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated, at least in part, by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. These findings suggest that ferroptosis-inducing agents may be combined with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway inhibitors to treat cancer patients. This combination therapy may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer patients. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) is the most common treatment for hypertension. However, the use of these drugs is associated with the development of heart failure. Our study shows that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism that involves the activation of STIM/ORAI channels. Our findings have important implications for the use of these drugs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of forest birds, but that the policy failed to reverse the decline of older forest-associated species. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral ecosystems, which are critical for forest birds and other species. These findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study provide a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes and to other pathogens. (Show more)

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become ubiquitous in the past 50 y. This study shows that the use of such devices in the hours before bedtime has important consequences for sleep. The results suggest that the use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment in the hours before bedtime may have a significant impact on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a short-term cooling event that occurred 12,900 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the Younger Dryas boundary (YDB). We show that bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust (= 1.3), indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium (Os) in these samples. The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is complex and depends on the stage of life at which it is deleted.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 1,460 beetle species to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, and the diversification of beetles. Our results suggest that the evolution of plant feeding was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that degrade plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work also provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in antibody engineering. This work is expected to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we find that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely to occur than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase under the conditions of the inner core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our study also suggests that the inner core is likely to be composed of a mixture of the hexagonal close-packed and body-centered cubic phases. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. It also provides a clue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. (Abridged)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and addiction behaviors.

We present a systematic study of the language processing system in the human brain, using the most powerful artificial neural networks ever trained. We find that the language system is highly predictive, and that the predictive power of the system is strongly correlated with its accuracy on a challenging language task. These results provide computational evidence for the fundamental role of predictive processing in language comprehension.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the use of algorithms that are not stable. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they are sufficient for the existence of stable algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community is currently debating the causes of the pandemic. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is the main cause. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Despite its critical design flaws, this experiment is still cited as a canonical study. Here, we discuss the flaws of the experiment and its implications for science and society.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. Despite this, we still do not know the identity of the causative agent. We sequenced the genome of a patient with diffuse lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the leprosy bacillus. We found that the leprosy bacilli have undergone extensive reductive evolution, and that the two pathogens are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation.

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we provide a complete solution for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a set of quasiparticles, which are the quantum counterparts of the classical solitons. We provide a complete description of the quasiparticle spectrum and their dynamics, which is in perfect agreement with numerical simulations. Our result provides a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to stop the pandemic. In this study, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated and can be manufactured in large quantities. This vaccine candidate is expected to be a candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and recurrent epidemics. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) was characterized by high mortality and frequent epidemics. The vector of the disease is unknown, and the mechanisms of transmission are poorly understood. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by humans during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353). This has implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe. Our model can be used to study the history of plague in Europe and other regions. It can also be used to study the history of human ectoparasites.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in the study of animal cognition. The evolution of brain size is often used as a proxy for the evolution of brain function. However, to get a less biased picture of the evolutionary paths leading to high cognitive power, we need to compare brains not by mass but by numbers of neurons, which are their basic computational units. This study reconstructs the evolution of brains across amniotes by directly analyzing neuron numbers by using the largest dataset of its kind and including essential data on reptiles. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This would have implications for the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of the dynamic actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds to actin filaments and induces severing in a mechanical-torque-dependent manner. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide insights into the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action and may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling actin dynamics. Fructose, a common sweetener, is widely used in the food supply. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on appetite and food intake. They also have implications for the development of strategies to reduce the consumption of fructose.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestries. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique. We found that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed, and that the settlement happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way. These results suggest that Madagascar is a unique case in the world, and that the history of Madagascar is not only different from other islands in the Indian Ocean, but also from the rest of Africa. This is important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. It also has implications for the study of human evolution and the peopling of the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a massive-scale effect, with people experiencing the same emotions as others, even when they are not in direct contact with those others. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The study of RNA structure and function has been a major focus of research for decades. More recently, the study of RNA modifications has become a major focus of research. In this study, we focus on one of the most common modifications found in coding regions of messenger RNA (mRNA), pseudouridine (Ψ). We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a modest impact on translation. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of mRNA modifications in gene expression and for the design of experiments to study the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of this temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at 37 °C, and that this is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen because it allows it to increase its virulence and biofilm-inducing activity. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and the risk they pose to aquatic biodiversity. Our results show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the quality of global surface water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. The virus has also infected a wide variety of animals, including wildlife. The potential for SARS-CoV-2 to spread between humans and animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the pandemic. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is common in North America. Our findings suggest that the virus has been circulating in deer for several months, and that the virus has spread between deer. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the challenges of building them, and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the number of affected individuals is expected to increase dramatically in the coming decades. The disease is characterized by the presence of extracellular deposits of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein, which are thought to be the primary causes of neuronal death. However, we show here that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is also toxic to the cell, and that this process may be the primary cause of the early inflammatory response in AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for its use for economic purposes is, however, still unknown. Here we present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. We further show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of the domestic chicken and its spread in the ancient world. (Less)

We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of large proteins at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to the maltose binding protein, a large protein that is known to fold through a native-like intermediate. The intermediate is a transient state that is not present in the native state. The results indicate that the intermediate is an obligatory step on the folding pathway and that the protein folds in more than one step.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a major factor in the regulation of gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to be the predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, is the primary enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped transcripts in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress. This enzyme prefers Np4-capped RNAs as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts, and it generates monophosphorylated RNAs as the primary product of decapping. These results suggest that the unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, resulting in a two-step process for the deprotection of capped RNAs. This process could have major implications for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although the immune system is the main player in the resolution of sepsis, the mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring arginine levels and T cell function in sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all animals on land and in the sea. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the global biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for quantum computing, but its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work provides a new route to explore the electronic properties of diamond, which can be used to understand the fundamental physics of diamond, and to tailor the properties of diamond for applications in quantum technologies.

The discovery of the first antifungal peptide, defensin, in plants has opened up a new avenue for the development of plant-derived antifungal compounds. This study describes the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides from the legume Medicago truncatula. These peptides are highly diverse in sequence and exhibit potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The structure of one of the peptides, NCR044, was solved by NMR spectroscopy. The structure was largely disordered and dynamic, but the presence of a disulfide bond stabilized a short α-helix and a β-sheet. The peptide also exhibited potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of the peptide was studied using microscopy and phosphoinositide binding studies. The results suggest that the peptide binds to the fungal cell wall and causes disruption of the plasma membrane and subsequent loss of turgor and death of the fungal germlings. The discovery of this new class of antifungal peptides has opened up a new avenue for the development of plant-derived antifungal compounds. This study also provides a structural basis for the mode of action of these peptides. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of the male reproductive tract is distinct from that of the female reproductive tract, and we identify a set of female-derived proteins that associate with the sperm and support their viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We report that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of mutations in VWF, explaining pathophysiology. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the force-dependent pathway is the dominant mechanism of VWF activation in vivo. These results provide a mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF and suggest that force may be a mechanism for regulating other proteins in vivo. This is important for understanding the effects of force on the body, including the cardiovascular system

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive view of the human virome, and the results are used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and diseases. The results are expected to advance the study of the human microbiome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has been estimated from the isotopic composition of marine cherts to have decreased from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. However, this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. Here, we present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Abridged)

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the main targets of drugs. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the normal function of the body and are also involved in the pathogenesis of many diseases. In this study, we found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel has a unique feature of slow C-type inactivation/recovery, which is state-dependent and closed-state dependent. This study provides a new perspective on the mechanism of the BK channel’s closing and the regulation of ion flow. It also provides a new target for the treatment of diseases caused by the BK channel’s dysfunction. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the world today. The parasite, Plasmodium, invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle and cause disease. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the host cell in the process is largely ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces, which, in turn, would have major implications for the development of antimalarial drugs. This work also provides a new perspective on the role of the erythrocyte in malaria pathogenesis.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for quantum computing, but its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the electronic properties of diamond for quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. These insights may be useful for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection. This article is protected by copyright

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does so, however, remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to the addition of each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a merge operation. We also show that the brain responds to the addition of each word or phrase with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, suggesting that the merge operation applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Finally, we show that the brain responds to the addition of each word or phrase with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, suggesting that the merge operation applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with a neural implementation of a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide a neurophysiological basis for the linguistic notion of a merge operation.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for the development of the nervous system and the immune system. It is also important for the development of the digestive system. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers a tissue-specific response to the two forms of Axin.

Obesity is a major public health problem, and the mechanisms that govern overeating are not well understood. Here we report the characterization of a brain circuit that may promote overeating. This circuit is located in the hypothalamus and is involved in the regulation of food intake. We show that electrical stimulation of this circuit causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is involved in the regulation of food intake, as lesions of the circuit disrupt the eating response to stimulation. Finally, we show that this circuit may promote overeating, as lesions of the circuit do not alter body weight. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may help to identify new targets for the treatment of obesity. (Show more)

Nitrogen is the primary limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the establishment of the biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) symbiosis is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we report the development of a system for the control of the BNF symbiosis in barley, in which the plant can regulate the expression of genes that control the onset of the symbiosis. This system is based on the use of rhizopine, a signaling molecule produced by bacteria that colonize the root cortex of cereal crops. We have developed a rhizopine-producing barley line and a rhizopine-sensitive bacterial strain, which allows for the control of the onset of the symbiosis in the field. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to improve the efficiency of N2-fixing crops and to reduce the use of synthetic nitrogen fertilizers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. The program was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management. However, the program’s impact on forest outcomes is likely to be limited by the fact that the program’s monitors are not the only authorities in the communities and that the monitors’ patrols are substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed over 1.5 million lives worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in containing the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be manufactured at a large scale, with the potential to produce billions of doses annually. The vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, which is known to be the primary target of neutralizing antibodies. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to the RBD from two recently reported SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern (501Y.V1/V2). Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. The vaccine candidate is expected to be a cost-effective and scalable intervention for the global pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of the ALK/ALKALS family of receptor tyrosine kinases in the development of the nervous system is not fully understood. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALS can activate the zebrafish ALK/ALKALS in vivo, which leads to the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALS in the development of the nervous system and suggest that ALKALS may be promising targets for the treatment of neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the deadliest diseases in human history, and the bacterium that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout the world. The emergence of Y. pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a story of rapid evolution and adaptation, and the study of ancient genomes has allowed us to reconstruct the early history of this pathogen. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, and show that the pathogen underwent a period of rapid dispersal and diversification across Eurasia. We also discover the presence of a flea-adapted form of the pathogen in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of the pathogen than previously thought. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague and its early evolution and adaptation. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and the role of masculinity in the 2020 presidential election.

The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 80% of the world’s grasslands. The fate of the remaining grasslands is uncertain, as they are often degraded and vulnerable to conversion to cropland. However, grasslands can also be managed to sequester carbon in the soil. This study shows that the management of grasslands in the United States can sequester carbon in the soil, and that this carbon sequestration can be enhanced by the integration of livestock and legumes into annual cropping systems. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester carbon and the importance of integrating livestock and legumes into annual cropping systems to achieve this goal.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. The top 12 were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans.

Nectar is the reward that flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is thought to be an important cue for pollinators, but the chemical basis for this cue is unknown. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a similar red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. We demonstrate that nesocodin is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator Phelsuma geckos. Our work provides evidence for convergent evolution of a visual cue in two different vertebrate-pollinated species. This work also identifies a small number of compounds that are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of visual signals in nature. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women who lived in southern Germany about 1,500 years ago. The results indicate that they had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that some of them had artificial skull deformations, which may have been related to their genetic ancestry. Finally, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and its bat coronavirus ancestors. They also suggest that the use of DPP4-recognizing bat

We describe the use of a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a larger national outbreak. Our findings highlight the utility of mNGS for pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response.

The human genome is replicated in the nucleus of the cell. The process is complex and requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). We have developed a series of unique kinetic assays to study the processivity and stability of pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as previously thought. This study provides a better understanding of the role of pol δ in eukaryotic DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first successful in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The polymerase is able to replicate RNA, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Thus, the polymerase can be used to study the origin of life, and it may be a component of the first RNA-based cells.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of cities over time and to study the causes and consequences of urban change. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and the mortality rate was reduced. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to eukaryotic cells. The ability to regulate copper homeostasis is therefore an important aspect of eukaryotic biology. In this study, we report the discovery of a fungal natural product that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The discovery of this natural product, xancin, and its role in copper homeostasis in Aspergillus fumigatus has implications for our understanding of the role of natural products in fungal biology and interactions with other microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of natural products in fungal biology and interactions with other microbes. (Read more)

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature, high-pressure polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant for understanding the nature of the sedimentary environment and the source of the sediment. The sedimentary environment is likely to be a “Lake Gale” catchment, and the sediment source is the crater wall/rim/central peak. The sedimentary environment is likely to be a “Lake Gale” catchment, and the sediment source is the crater wall/rim/central peak.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of agricultural and forestry systems. The geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood, and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants and animals is largely unknown. Here, we use a large dataset of leaf-out and leaf-freezing resistance traits to infer the evolutionary adaptations of woody species to frost events. We find that species in regions with frequent frost events are cautious in their leaf-out strategies, while species in regions with infrequent frost events are opportunistic. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we demonstrate that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Our findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by motor neuron toxicity. However, the toxicity of motor neuron-derived factors to other cell types, such as astrocytes, is poorly understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-derived astrocytes from living ALS patients. This will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of therapies to alleviate toxicity to other cell types. This method will also enable the study of the disease process in the living patient. This will be of great importance for the study of ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. We now show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma. We demonstrate that the ability of antifreeze glycoprotein to alter the gut microbiota is due to its ability to bind the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of strategies to control the transmission of human pathogens by ticks. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. The discovery of a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail ending in a pygostyle (Pygostylia) provides new insights into the evolution of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the system without a detailed understanding of the processes that are occurring within the system. In this paper, we show that the behavior of the climate system can be understood in terms of the behavior of the water vapor in the stratosphere.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can affect its ability to hide from predators, attract mates, or be camouflaged in its environment. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color of the animals is determined by a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is formed when hemoglobin is degraded. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, the phenomenon of having blue-green tissues, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates and the role of serpins in the body’s defense against proteases.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the hypoxic tumor microenvironment is a major driver of cancer progression. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, a demethylase that demethylates NANOG mRNA, which encodes a pluripotency factor. This, in turn, leads to enrichment of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs), which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for the identification of the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. Understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depends on an accurate and precise age model. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier against the invasion of pathogens and the immune system. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the first site of immune attack in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), such as Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling is critical for the control of inflammatory responses in IECs. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD.
