The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in the D614G mutant form and show that this form is more flexible and open than the wild-type form. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and facilitate the fusion process.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Munier [19] for finite games. The proof is constructive, and we provide a procedure for finding an ε-equilibrium. The result is of independent interest, and it is also a step toward the construction of a general theory of repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, and by 0.87 y at age 65 y, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as physics, biology, and geology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt are pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them are electron acceptors. Our results are of great interest for the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure, and they are also of interest for the understanding of the chemical behavior of compounds under pressure. Our results are also of interest for the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms in the solar system, and for the prediction of the chemical behavior of atoms in other planets and stars.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of fire activity over the past century. This has led to a warming of the climate, which may be reversed by recent reductions in fire activity. However, this is contingent on continued reductions in emissions, and the risk of more extreme fires is not eliminated. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to understand the effects of fire on climate change.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan to a symbiotic bacterium is sufficient to maintain its population in the host organ, and that this glycan is only provided at night. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the acidification of the host organ, and this acidification is necessary for the symbiont to produce light at night. We propose that this strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their symbionts. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of symbioses. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a sparse representation of word embeddings to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We then use these atoms to model the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. Our method can also be used to identify gender biases in topics. We provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method can be extended to other domains of interest. We hope it will be useful to researchers and practitioners.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The climate conditions that prevailed in the years preceding the outbreaks of the Black Death have been the subject of intense debate. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics were not caused by a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, but rather by repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the climate conditions that prevailed in the years preceding the Black Death were not favorable for the establishment of the disease in Europe. This finding has implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the Black Death. (Less)

We report the discovery of a densovirus (Parvoviridae) as the likely cause of asteroid mass mortality on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus causing a disease in asteroids. The discovery of this virus is important for understanding the ecology of asteroid populations and the role of viruses in the dynamics of marine communities.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. We have identified IL1RAP (IL1R3) as a target for treatment of AML. We show that the antibody targeting IL1RAP is effective in xenograft models of AML, and we demonstrate that the antibody is effective in the treatment of AML in mice. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers as well. Thus, the results provide important insights into the treatment of AML and may have implications for the treatment of other cancers.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island has been isolated for a long time, and its population is one of the most isolated in the world. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island has been colonized by different waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The distribution of the genomic diversity across the island shows that the colonization was not homogeneous, and that the population was not already admixed before the arrival of the first people. The results suggest that Madagascar has been colonized by different waves of people, and that the population was not already admixed before the arrival of the first people. This is important for understanding the human history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy language. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These results suggest that the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to regulate carbon utilization genes. The protein may also have other functions. This work provides insight into the role of the protein in the cell. It also provides a model for how the protein may interfere with the ability of the RNA to regulate gene expression. This model may be applicable to other sRNA-encoding genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work also provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in antibody engineering. This work is expected to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their data is often not used in agricultural decision-making because it is difficult to integrate into quantitative models. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts across the US, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We demonstrate that the Crop Condition Index, which is based on this survey, can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results suggest that the survey data can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies, which can be used to improve agricultural decision-making. This approach can be extended to other countries and crops.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be supported by a combination of mechanisms. Here we propose a model of language processing that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This work is important for understanding the role of soil respiration in the global carbon cycle and its response to climate change.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of the plant lineage. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our model provides a framework for understanding the evolution of the plastid genome and its impact on the evolution of the plant lineage. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the city of Cape Town’s history. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our findings are important for understanding the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought and for planning for the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron enzyme. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. A diiron enzyme in the betaproteobacterium Rubrivivax gelatinosus rescues the loss of its cyanobacterial ortholog, cycI, in Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803, and the two enzymes are interchangeable in this organism. Conversely, coexpression of cyanobacterial cycI and ycf54 is

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS) and experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is a complex process involving multiple cell types, and the role of neuroinflammation in EAE remains unclear. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in the pathophysiology of EAE. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for EAE and other neuroinflammatory diseases.

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm, and that additional global warming is very likely to increase the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that affects social interaction and communication. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Our results suggest that behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing new therapeutic approaches. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including hematological abnormalities. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions.

The study of the spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a major focus of research in neurodegenerative diseases. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to study the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the spread of aggregates in the brain and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as important reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, named MTX, selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings also provide a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of viral spillover from bats and may lead to the development

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) 1 and 2, and have shown that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously resistant to treatment. Thus, our work provides a metabolic target for cancer therapy, and a metabolic vulnerability for lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons and is caused by mutations in a number of proteins. Here, we show that the proteins that are found in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS is a consequence of the disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. This finding has implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystals are predicted to produce exotic atom–light interaction behaviors, including suppressed spontaneous decay, photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal, and atom–light interactions that are anisotropic in the plane of the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The photonic crystal devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals are expected to be applicable to other systems of interacting particles.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has allowed us to understand the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using sequences from living organisms. However, viruses are often transmitted from one generation to the next by infecting the remains of the previous generation. Here we present the genomes of five ancient viruses from human remains that lived from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that viruses can be transmitted over long distances and that they have been part of the human evolutionary history for thousands of years. (Less)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of rise, which is higher than previous estimates. The paper also provides a new estimate of the rate of acceleration, which is higher than previous estimates. The paper provides a new estimate of the rate of acceleration, which is higher than previous estimates.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a critical piece of information for understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain, and the structure of the enzyme–transition state complex is even more difficult to obtain. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to obtain the structure of the enzyme–transition state complex, and then use this structure to understand the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that was recently approved for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, given the current global pandemic. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host signals the provision of a specific nutrient, and the consequences of such a signal for the symbiont, are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is provided just before dusk, when the squid’s symbiotic organ is at its most metabolically active. We propose that this strategy is used by hosts to regulate the activities of their symbionts, and that it may be a general feature of animal-microbe interactions.

This study has implications for the future of education. It shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools, and that this can be achieved through a scalable, online intervention. It also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships is a powerful predictor of student behavior.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Our study provides important mechanistic insights into the transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will be of great importance for understanding the impact of DNA alkylation on the accuracy of DNA replication and transcription.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. To understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first S protein cleavage events. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal fusion-activating proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S protein cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This study provides robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. The results suggest that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available from 25 to 50% (e.g., from 1 in 4 to 2 in 4 options) increased vegetarian meal sales by 15% in a large-scale field study. This increase was not accompanied by a decrease in meat meal sales, suggesting that the effect was not a rebound effect. The results also suggest that the effect was concentrated among diners with the lowest levels of vegetarian meal selection. The findings have implications for catering practices in the food service industry and for the design of interventions to promote more plant-based diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to communicate with the extracellular space. Here we use a quantitative proteomics approach to study the surfaceome of a collection of six oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We also complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major advance in our understanding of the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome. It also provides a resource for the study of the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome in cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout and vote share. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail programs are not likely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This dimerization interface is likely important for the unique immune suppression and evasion activities of ORF8. These activities may be important in the rapid spread of the disease. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of many diseases. In this study, we found that hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. We also found that CRF, acting through CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε in astrocytes, which contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this disease. (Show more)

The era of big data has brought with it a new challenge for statistical inference. Having found associations in a data set, how do we assess their significance? This paper describes a new approach to selective inference, which is needed because we have “cherry picked” the associations that we wish to study. The new approach is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We illustrate the new approach in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The new approach is general and can be applied to any statistical learning method. It is a welcome development in the era of big data.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step for the formation of functional vascular networks. However, the development of ECs has been difficult to achieve in vitro and in vivo. Here, we report the development of endothelial cells (ECs) from human fibroblasts using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). The ETV2-induced ECs (ETVECs) exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vascular networks in vivo. This study provides a new approach for the development of ECs and the generation of vascular networks. Thus, the development of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The discovery of the “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of their physiological ligands. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that the augmentor ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. Deficiency in augmentor ligands results in strong impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish that is phenocopied in zebrafish deficient in Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of RTKs in development and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the treatment of T2D is still a challenge. In this study, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING-deficient mice showed impaired glucose homeostasis and insulin secretion. STING-deficient β-cells showed decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired insulin secretion. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is a major advantage for the virus. However, the packaging of the genome is not optimal, and the virus has to overcome this limitation. Here, we identified a mechanism that allows the virus to overcome this limitation. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of the virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction we identified is a mechanism that the virus uses to overcome the limitation of the genome packaging. This mechanism is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results have implications for the evolution of the virus and for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells (ECs). The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that were extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies from 1992 to 2012, and examine geographic and seasonal extents of human-ignited wildfires relative to lightning-ignited wildfires. Humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of cities over time and to study the physical dynamics of urban change. This work is important for understanding the physical appearance of cities and for understanding the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, but the recent surge in cases has prompted global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the rate of viral production, the time between cell infection and viral production, the rate of viral production, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can be used to guide the development of treatment strategies for the current outbreak. Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, yet they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In particular, the recent increase in ocean temperatures due to climate change is causing widespread bleaching events. Our study provides insights into the underlying causes of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is a key step in the progression of bleaching. We show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts are altered during heat stress, leading to a shift from carbon uptake to release by the coral holobiont. This, in turn, promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which ultimately leads to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in the future.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication between the host and the microbiome. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and promote tumor growth. We also identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing therapeutic strategies to control intestinal tumorigenesis. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for breast cancer, but the response to treatment varies widely among patients. We show that the expression of the ROR1 receptor is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which enhances the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also show that the expression of ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This article

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which is thought to have led to a reduction in Southern Hemisphere precipitation and a subsequent collapse of the Southern Hemisphere summer monsoons. We show that the start of deglaciation was preceded by a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and sustainability assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human and environmental stress. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries are a priority for conservation and sustainability efforts.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The aqueous energy storage system is considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular control of regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS and for developing new strategies for regenerative medicine.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic variation in the genome. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a key determinant of the rate of evolution in a species. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, and others showing intense levels of recombination. The distribution of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting state of the brain is a complex and dynamic process, which is difficult to study. In this work, we used a nonfluctuating imaging technique, positron emission tomography, to identify and validate the resting state of the human brain. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the resting state networks in healthy subjects and during task performance. We found that the default mode network was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct method for studying the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for translation initiation and is involved in mRNA stability. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because it is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of NAD+ in health and disease. They also provide a model for the discovery of additional 5′ modifications in eukaryotes. (Read more)

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the study of metabolic memory. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results may help to understand the mechanisms of metabolic memory and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier and behavioral disorders, which may be important factors in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for studying the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds. The production of these compounds is essential for the development and ripening of fruit, and the quality of the fruit is largely determined by the composition of the volatile bouquet. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato volatiles and will be of interest to the research community. It also provides a starting point for the development of improved tomato cultivars with enhanced flavor. (Read more)

This is important because temperature change is one of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the map of local space, but the organization of its neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be the main neurons involved in the formation of the map of local space, are organized separately from other neurons. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and will be useful for understanding the function of this region in navigation. This article is protected by copyright. Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene, which is known to be involved in the regulation of flowering time, is not required for the flowering of the host plant, but is required for the flowering of the parasite plant. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We have long sought to understand how we know when two people are connected. In this work, we show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of language, the development of social networks, and the design of social technologies.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its function is dependent on the proper functioning of its components. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the function of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in the accumulation of Si and the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to control insect pests. This study also provides a model for understanding the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of other lipids in macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of multiple streams of information. Here we propose a model of language processing that is based on the integration of information over time. We show that the dynamics of the neural code can support the binding of information over time. This is achieved through a mechanism that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. Our model provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and that the size, shape, and geometry of the DNA nanostructures are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. Our work also provides a platform for the development of new tools for plant biology.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes is from nonpoint sources, which are diffuse and difficult to track. We show that the majority of the daily nutrient load to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, is delivered by a small fraction of its tributaries. These findings have implications for the management of coastal eutrophication, which is often driven by the same sources as inland lakes.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. Our results suggest that the presence of rare, but strong, forcing events may be a general feature of complex systems, and that the ability to exploit such events may be a key factor in the emergence of long-lived, far-from-equilibrium states.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, which are believed to be caused by disruption of the NMDAR. We use a dynamic model of the brain to show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the brain, and that these changes can be used to explain the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work offers mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. These findings may help in the development of new therapies for NMDAR-Abs encephalitis. The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and the history of carbon perturbation events is a key component of the history of abrupt climate change. Here, we present a study of one such event, which occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of tropical deforestation-associated carbon emissions. As a result, many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations (∼188,000 km2) in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire from 2001 to 2015.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrate species, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In many species, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In others, multiple alleles at a single locus determine sex, and the sex of an individual can be any of several possible genotypes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles at a single locus on the secondary sexual characteristics of a cichlid fish.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive carbonyl species. These species are generated by photooxidation of the vitamin A aldehyde lipofuscin and photodegradation of the vitamin A aldehyde retinal. The retina is also challenged by the presence of iron, which is a cofactor for the photooxidation of lipofuscin and the photodegradation of retinal. We show that iron levels in the retina impact the levels of lipofuscin and retinal, and that this impact is mediated by the presence of iron. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key factor in the structure of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of siphonophore predators is modular, and that the evolution of their specialized feeding strategies is linked to the evolution of their specialized tentacles. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of predator specialization, and for the study of the evolution of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and the earliest hominin hands are incomplete. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene to recent period that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human form. (Less)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) 1 and 2, and have shown that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously resistant to therapy. Thus, our work provides a metabolic target for cancer therapy, and a metabolic vulnerability for lymphoma.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is associated with a range of negative impacts on people’s health and livelihoods. However, little is known about the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. We show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by fragmentation of natural landscapes. Our findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 150% since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
